awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Pharmaceutical Engineering at Virginia Commonwealth University
awd_abstract_narration:
The REU site in Pharmaceutical Engineering at Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU)is co-sponsored by the VCU College of Engineering the VCU School of Pharmacy and Virginia State University (VSU). The 10-week program will annually engage 10 undergraduates and approximatley 20 faculty members in research projects in areas related to pharmaceutical engineering. Pharmaceutical Engineering REU projects will engage students in collaborative projects that have the potential to transform the quality, cost, and availability of medications, while enhancing global competitiveness of the US pharmaceutical and healthcare industries. The REU site seeks to inspire a diverse group of undergraduate students to pursue careers in the science and engineering of pharmaceutical products, thus addressing the growing need of a multidisciplinary workforce of researchers, educators, entrepreneurs and regulators capable of solving health challenges of the future. By working with undergraduate institutions with limited STEM education and research opportunities, and recruiting a diverse team of student researchers, we aim to increase participation in science and engineering from underrepresented groups. Each student cohort will participate in a co-curriculum comprised of seminars, workshops, field trips, and social activities with support from mentors from VCU, VSU and industrial partners. Students will gain skills in research, product innovation, scientific communication and publication writing, as well as teamwork, and grant writing.

The REU in Pharmaceutical Engineering at VCU will conduct research in three fundamental areas: i) the engineering of pharmaceutical materials; ii) the engineering of complex formulations and iii) the generation and control of active pharmaceutical ingredients. Students will gain skills and experiences by engaging in research that supports the development of complex and novel pharmaceutical products. REU students will be involved both in experimental work and also learn the theoretical concepts of pharmaceutical engineering that address interdisciplinary challenges related to the design and development of pharmaceutical products. The projects that will be undertaken address a growing need for a team-based approach to solving challenges related to pharmaceutical engineering and include topics in drug delivery, inhaled therapeutics, and continuous manufacturing, combination chemotherapy and nanomedicine.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Pharmaceutical Engineering REU at VCU successfully introduced over 40 undergraduate researchers to fundamental research in this field during a 10-week, in-person experience.  Students were recruited nationwide and locally with specific intent to include students from various educational backgrounds including i) research universities; ii) those 4-year institutions that have limited research capabilities; and iii) community colleges. These students carried out specific laboratory projects in relevant areas of Pharmaceutical Engineering such as, nanomedicine drug delivery, continuous manufacturing, de-novo enzyme design, inhalation therapy, machine learning-based process optimization, and drug encapsulation. Each undergraduate research was assigned a mentor(s) who provided project guidance and feedback on performance and helped them create scientific communications.  These students also benefited from interaction with a larger laboratory group including graduate students and post-docs. By participating in these research activities and the larger REU, the students were exposed to the collaborative nature and cross-functional expertise needed for research in Pharmaceutical Engineering. Each student presented weekly on their project for their fellow students and the REU Leadership team (Professors da Rocha, Ndip and Roper) whereby they recorded a 4-5 minute recorded update. These presentations incorporated the concepts of creating a hypothesis, specific aims and results.  The students participated in additional structured activities which would help them prepare for their next phase of education.  These activities included, career development concepts, providing feedback, applying to graduate school and research ethics. The students also participated in external activities in the Richmond area including a picnic at the Virginia Museum of Art, an escape room, and exploring the James River. At the end of the 10 weeks, the students prepared a poster for the summer ending symposium as well as a longer recorded presentation. In some years the symposium was combined with other VCU REUs to provide the students exposure to additional fields of science and engineering. Finally, the students created a research report outlining their progress over the course of the summer.

The REU in Pharmaceutical Engineering was very successful in encouraging students to pursue graduate education, many in the science and engineering fields. Many students applied to PhD programs in Pharmaceutical Engineer, Biomedical Engineering and Chemistry due to their positive experience at the REU. In particular the impact of this REU in its core mission of encouraging future graduate work in Pharmaceutical Engineering was particularly notable.  In 2020 VCU initiated the Pharmaceutical Engineering PhD program in 2020 and has now grown to 24 students, 5 of which participated in the REU. Furthermore 2 other REU students are attending other related programs (Chemistry and Pharmaceutics) at VCU. Of additional significance is that several other PhD program students came from undergraduate schools of REU participants. Many other Pharmaceutical Engineering REU students attend PhD  programs at other universities. Overall the Pharmaceutical Engineering REU was extremely successful in recruiting students to the program, providing them with a valuable research experience, and delivering a student curriculum which helped them plan their future career development.
